Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of High-Flow Nasal Oxygen in High-Risk Cardiac Surgical Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: 100 adult patients scheduled for elective cardiac surgery were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included COPD, asthma, recent lower respiratory tract infection, BMI ≥35 kg/m², or heavy smoking.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive HFNO (n=51) or standard oxygen therapy (n=49)

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the efficacy of high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) in reducing hospital length of stay compared to standard oxygen therapy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hospital length of stay, measured from surgery to discharge.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via a centralised online system.

Blinding.evidence: Surgical and nursing teams responsible for discharge were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 adult patients scheduled for elective cardiac surgery were randomised 1:1

Number_Analysed.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive HFNO (n=51) or standard oxygen therapy (n=49)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The geometric mean hospital stay was 29% lower in the HFNO group (95% CI 11–44%, p=0.004).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.
